TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey-skeletal, mixed, superactive Typic Haplocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Jaroso cobbly loam, forested.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted)
01--2 inches to 0; needles, leaves, twigs, etc., in various stages of decomposition.
A21--0 to 4 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) cobbly loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak thin platy structure parting to weak fine granular; soft, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine and fine, few medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; 25 percent cobbles; 10 percent gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.5); abrupt smooth boundary.  (4 to 7 inches thick)
A22--4 to 16 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) cobbly heavy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak fine granular structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine and fine and few medium and coarse roots; few very fine tubular pores and many very fine interstitial pores; 5 percent stones, 15 percent cobbles, and 10 percent gravel; medium acid (pH 5.6); clear smooth boundary.  (8 to 12 inches thick)
B21t--16 to 26 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) gravelly heavy clay loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few medium, fine and very fine roots; common very fine interstitial pores; common thin clay films on peds and on rock fragments; 25 percent gravel, 10 percent cobbles; medium acid (pH 6.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 12 inches thick)
B22t--26 to 41 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) very gravelly clay, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; strong medium angular blocky structure; extremely hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine, fine and medium roots; common very fine interstitial pores; many thick clay films on peds and on rock fragments; 35 percent gravel, 10 percent cobbles, 5 percent stones; medium acid (pH 6.0); clear smooth boundary.  (10 to 18 inches thick)
B23t--41 to 53 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) extremely cobbly clay, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; moderate fine angular blocky structure; extremely hard, very firm, very sticky and very plastic; few very fine interstitial pores; many thick clay films on peds and common on rock fragments; 60 percent gravel, 30 percent cobbles, 5 percent stones; medium acid (pH 5.6); clear wavy boundary.  (10 to 14 inches thick)
B3t--53 to 60 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) extremely cobbly sandy clay, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4); weak very fine subangular blocky structure; extremely hard, very firm, sticky and plastic; few very fine tubular pores; many thick clay films on peds and on rock fragments; 60 percent gravel, 30 percent cobbles, 5 percent stones; medium acid (pH 5.8).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Colfax County, New Mexico; AMS Photo #1452, SW1/4 NE1/4 section 14, T.24N., R.15E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature is 36 to 40 degrees F. and the average summer soil temperature is 42 to 47 degrees F.  The solum is 60 to 84 inches thick.  Depth to the argillic horizon ranges from 12 to 18 inches.  Rock fragments are angular gravel, cobbles and stones of shale and sandstone.  Some pedons have a thin A1 horizon.
The A2 horizon has value of 6 or 7 dry and 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 or 4.  It is loam, very fine sandy loam, or light clay loam and has 20 to 50 percent rock fragments.
The B2t horizon has value of 5 through 7 dry and 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 through 6.  It is clay loam, sandy clay or clay and has 35 to 50 percent clay and 50 to 80 percent rock fragments.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Chris, Loberg, Nutras, Seitz and Vulcan series.  All of these soils except Loberg have montmorillonitic mineralogy.  Loberg soils have an A2 horizon less than 13 inches thick.  Also, they are slightly acid to moderately alkaline in the lower part of the profile.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Jaroso soils are on moderately sloping smooth sides of mountains and strongly sloping to steep sides of rough mountains.  Elevations are 9,000 to 11,000 feet.  These soils formed in material weathered from interbedded shale and sandstone and some limestone.  The climate is humid and the annual precipitation ranges from 25 to 40 inches.  About 70 percent of the precipitation comes in the form of snow and in most years the snowpack is in place as late as mid-June.  About 30 percent of the precipitation comes as summer storms.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Angostura, Maes, Mascarenas, and Presa soils.  Angostura and Presa soils have a loamy-skeletal family control section.  Maes soils lack a cryic temperature regime.  Depth to the argillic horizon in Mascarenas soils is below 24 inches.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium to rapid runoff; moderately slow to slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Used for timber production, seasonal grazing, water production, recreation, and wildlife habitat.  Vegetation is mainly Douglas-fir, Engelmann spruce, corkbark fir, white fir, aspen, kinnickinnick, Oregongrape, wild strawberries, mountain brome and other grasses and forbs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern New Mexico and possibly southern Colorado.  Jaroso soils are extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Taos Area, New Mexico, 1976.
OSED scanned by SSQA.  Last revised by state on 3/76.
